*What is it?*

Maps.ME is like Google Maps, but less creepy (doesn't constantly track you and use your location to serve better ads). At its core, it relies on the excellent [Open Street Map](https://www.openstreetmap.org/) project, which uses crowd sourcing to power its maps.

*Why is it dope?*

First, its ability to save maps offline makes it so that even without WiFi you're never lost. Also, users can easily submit notes / locations - which makes off the grid locations, such as ruins, parks, and natural areas that much easier to navigate. It's like have the collective knowledge of thousands of other travelers displayed on an information layer over your world. Dope.

### 2. The Culture Trip

**Website / iOS + Android**

![Culture Trip](data:image/png;base64,)

*What is it?*

The Culture Trip is essentially a Trip Advisor, but for less basic shit. Striving for low key experiences and more authentic cultural perspectives rather than the regular tourist traps, The Culture Trip is like having a friend who's a local from your destination city who could help show you the cool cuts of the place.

*Why is it dope?*

Because it fundamentally changes your itinerary if you refer to it as you travel, in a good way. It could even show you places you've already been to in a whole new way. Also, the lists and articles can be saved offline if you use the app, which can be great to reduce data consumption or refer to should you lack internet access. Dope.

### 3. Spendee

**Website / iOS + Android**

![Spendee](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/RQLZrFyXR3iMTvXy0-_K9B0GGhbx5rXfzQ9FFMKuWXxp4zb9V7XRwsT3mYGDY3MTaXs)

*What is it?*

Spendee is the first 'budgeting app' that I've ever used. I wouldn't say I use it for budgeting per se, I really use it to remain cognizant of just how much I'm spending. Because as you already may know, when you travel at a pretty steady clip it's easy to get lost in the currency conversions or just flat out lose track for of how much you're spending.  

*Why is it dope?*

The dopest thing about Spendee is that it accepts any currency and will then convert it after you input any transaction (I use the free tier where you have to manually input expenses. I actually prefer this since the act of manually inputting my costs makes me even more aware of how much I've been spending). It also has some real nice visualizations to help the guilt sink of just how much you ended up spending on drinks last night.

### 4. WhatsApp

**Desktop App / iOS + Android**

![WhatsApp](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

*What is it?*

This may seem obvious for most of the world, but for my fellow Americans and others who are still not in the know (I still meet many while traveling), WhatsApp is basically the lingua franca of messaging apps around the world. You will meet people, they will ask for your WhatsApp. So have it ready.

*Why is it dope?*

So you could keep in touch in a consistent way with people you meet on your travels. Also it's super minimal and free of clutter (almost to a fault), which is a fresh change of pace of other messaging apps with dozens of other features.

### 5. Anki

**Website / iOS + Android**

![Anki](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/PxHji1wxxjE/maxresdefault.jpg)

*What is it?*

Perhaps the least sexy app on this list, Anki is a SRS (Spaced Repetition Software) that happens to be incredibly useful for memorizing phrases and words in new languages. The idea behind [Spaced Repetition](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Spaced_repetition) is simple: recall is more important rote memorization - so in contrast to other flashcard apps, Anki waits until you're about to forget a word and then drills you on it. This forces a recall and further etches the concept into your memory.

*Why is it dope?*

You know what's dope? Being a [polyglot](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Polyglotism). I don't want to go over the intrinsic benefits of learning at least some basic phrases in the countries you choose to go to, so what I will say is that I have tried many, many apps for language learning - DuoLingo, Quizlet, Memrise, etc. What makes Anki unique is that it actually works - if you regularly quiz yourself according to the pace it sets and make new flashcards as you need them, you'll find yourself committing phrases to memory, thus gaining the respect and admiration of the people in your host country. Super dope.

## Honorable Mention(s)

### Couchsurfing

![Couchsurfing](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

Chances are you might've heard of Couchsurfing already, but let's just sum it up by saying that Couchsurfing was actually one of the market validators for Airbnb. Couchsurfing is basically a free version of Airbnb, but driven by a mutual passion for cultural interchange and exploration rather than a profit motive. Not only is Couchsurfing great if you're trying to travel for cheap, features like Hangouts and Events make it so that you could also use the app to meet new people. I even recently used Events to join in a road trip in Costa Rica, which ended up being on the highlights of my trip üíØüá®üá∑

### Meetup / Eventbrite

![Meetup](https://proxy.duckduckgo.com/iu/?u=http%3A%2F%2Fgutocarvalho.net%2Foctopress%2Fimages%2Fmeetup.jpg&f=1)

I'll just group these two together for brevity's sake. Many people think it's a bit strange when I recommend these apps for traveling, as they're usually thought of as platforms used back home, exactly when you're not traveling. But don't be mistaken, the reach of both Meetup and Eventbrite is more global than you might think, and I've used both to attend language meetups, weird tech conferences, and a plethora of other offbeat (and particularly non-touristy) gatherings in cities around the world

### Wrap up

Alrighty, so what're you waiting for? Each of these apps can add a new dimension in your travel experience so get to downloading them! If I missed something obvious or you think one of these apps in total nonsense, be sure to let me know in the comments below. Happy travels üåè!
